From Narita to Tokyo! Compare Travel Times and Prices for 5 Transportation Options
When traveling to Tokyo, you can use Narita Airport and Haneda Airport. Generally, Narita Airport is a popular choice for many travelers due to its various f...

When traveling to Tokyo, you can use Narita Airport and Haneda Airport.
Generally, Narita Airport is a popular choice for many travelers due to its various flights, affordable fares, and frequent discounts.
However, as it is about 60 km away from downtown Tokyo, there are various transportation options to consider.
In this article, let's explore the most common five modes of transportation and recommend the best option for different situations.
Narita Express is a special express train operated by JR East. It is often referred to as N'EX.
Each seat is equipped with a power outlet and a table.
There are luggage racks in the train aisles that you can hook up and lock.
The train has restrooms, and a snack cart offers food and beverages.
There are two main directions: Hachioji and Ofuna.
For Hachioji, most trains operate only up to Shinjuku, with only two trains a day continuing beyond.

Trains from Narita Airport split at Tokyo Station, with trains 1 through 6 going to Ofuna and trains 7 through 12 going to Hachioji,
so if you sit in a seat other than your assigned one, you may end up at an unwanted destination.
The departure intervals are usually 30 minutes for Shinjuku-bound and 1 hour for Omiya-bound trains.
From Narita Airport Terminal 1, the travel time is as follows:

Tokyo 3,070 Round-trip ¥5,000 
 Shinagawa, Shibuya, Shinjuku 3,250 
 Yokohama 4,370 
 Omiya 4,700
💡 The N'EX round-trip ticket can be used with different stations for arrival and departure. For example, you can alight at Shinjuku when entering and depart from Shibuya when leaving.
There is a yellow designated area marked as
on the route map. Within this area, you can alight at any station without additional charges as long as you don't exit through the ticket gates after getting off the N'EX.

For example, after alighting at Shinjuku, you can transfer to the JR Yamanote Line to Ikebukuro or, after alighting at Ofuna, transfer to the JR Shonan-Shinjuku Line to Kamakura without additional charges.
Skyliner is a special express train operated by Keisei Electric Railway.
Each seat is equipped with a power outlet.
Carriage racks are available for luggage.
Convenience facilities with restrooms and vending machines are available in designated areas.
. Depending on the time, Shin-Kamagaya and Aoto may not be served.
For easy transfers, Nippori is convenient for JR lines, and Keisei Ueno is convenient for subway (Tokyo Metro and Toei Subway) connections.
At Nippori, the JR platforms are right upstairs after alighting from Nippori Station.
At Keisei Ueno, you can transfer to the subway by using the No. 6 exit of Ueno Station.

Shin-Kamagaya 1,730 Round-trip ¥4,880 
 Aoto 2,190 
 Nippori 2,570 
 Keisei Ueno 2,570
Keisei Access Express is a regular commuter train operated by JR East.
There are two main directions: Haneda Airport and Nishimagome.
it operates as an express on the Asakusa Line
, stopping only at major stations such as
A network of buses offering specialized routes at affordable prices. The drawback is that only one suitcase per person is allowed.

Bus services operating to various locations in the 23 wards of Tokyo, Chiba Prefecture, and Kanagawa Prefecture. The fare is relatively high at ¥3,600 for a one-way trip from Tokyo Station, but it can be a convenient option if there is a bus stop near your accommodation. Due to the impact of COVID-19, some routes may be temporarily suspended or have schedule changes, so it's advisable to check the timetable before making a reservation.

A must when traveling abroad! Tips for comparing mobile internet options: USIM · eSIM · Pocket Wi-Fi and Data roaming
When it comes to using mobile internet abroad, there are several options to consider: eSIM, USIM, pocket Wi-Fi, and data roaming. Each option has its own adv...
💡 This article is based on mobile data plans in South Korea.

When it comes to using mobile internet abroad, there are several options to consider: eSIM, USIM, pocket Wi-Fi, and data roaming.
Each option has its own advantages and disadvantages, and their strengths complement each other, making it challenging to determine an absolute best choice.
The decision often depends on individual preferences regarding convenience, speed, and price.

In this article, we will explore the pros and cons of each option and compare them in terms of convenience, speed, and price.
To facilitate the price comparison, let's assume a

USIM is a physical SIM card that allows you to use the local carrier's SIM card in the country you are traveling to,
similar to how you would use a locally activated service from the carrier.
Pros: It offers fast and cost-effective service as it directly utilizes the local carrier's network.

Cons: SIM replacement might be cumbersome, and caution is needed to prevent loss or damage.
Additionally, you won't receive calls or texts on your original number.
💡 It was calculated including the delivery fee because the delivery fee is added both when sending it to the airport terminal and when receiving it by courier.
eSIM, or embedded SIM, is a digital form of SIM that is built into the device. Like USIM, it utilizes the local carrier's network, providing fast connectivity.

Pros: It can be used in dual SIM mode alongside your existing USIM.
Calls and texts use your home carrier, while data uses the local carrier.
Cons: It's a relatively newer technology, and not all smartphones support eSIM.
💡 For SKT users, connecting to data roaming or Wi-Fi abroad with a Korean SIM card
activates the T Phone app in baro mode

.
During this mode, you can use your Korean number for calls and texts for
free, especially when connected to Wi-Fi
Also known as a mobile router, it's simply a

that you can take with you.
It is relatively slower than USIM or eSIM as it relies on the local carrier through the home carrier.
Pros: It can connect multiple devices simultaneously and is the most economical option for multiple users.
Cons: Handling, return, damage, and monitoring battery levels can be cumbersome.
One free day for 3 or more days of usage (excluding Japan/Asia).
Long-term discounts applied for 6 days or more.

A service that allows travelers to use the local carrier's network through a partnership with the traveler's home carrier.
No need to purchase or install a SIM card separately.
Pros: Convenient as you can use your smartphone without additional setup.
Cons: Relatively expensive compared to other options.
Free calls with baro calls, no data deduction.

The listed products are fixed with a certain number of days, with KT offering 5 days and U+ offering 3 days.
If you need to use roaming for more than the fixed duration, you will have to opt for a relatively more expensive product that allows you to specify the number of days.
Below is a list of products configured with the cheapest options.
: eSIM > USIM > Pocket Wi-Fi > Data Roaming
: Pocket Wi-Fi > eSIM > USIM > Data Roaming
Data Roaming > USIM > eSIM > Pocket Wi-Fi
USIM = eSIM > Data Roaming >= Pocket Wi-Fi
